Team Fortress 2 is, at heart, a gloriously simple game that's been created with style, panache and an undeniable love of gaming. It's the kind of game that you want to show to people who don't play games so that they understand and then either get involved or go away. There is life before Team Fortress 2, and there is life after. After is better.

This game is just really really fun. It's fun to screw around, it's fun to tryhard in valve servers, it's fun to play competitively, its fun to play jump maps, and it's fun to go to ridiculously modded community servers which make you download sounds called 'ScoutAnimeDeathScream57.ogg'. All of this game is fun, and even though TF2 doesn't get support anymore all the classes are well balanced and enjoyable and every weapon in this game is fun to use, if not necessarily competitively viable.

I really think that the only problems with this game is the lack of support from the developers.

With about 450 hours into the game, I think I need to re-write my review of this game. I know what you may be thinking, "450 hours isn't a whole lot for a game like this". Let me tell you this, I don't care. I do believe that I am a decent enough player to write a detailed review of this game, despite my relatively 'small' amount of hours put into the game. 

Let me just say, this game is really good. Like, really good. Valve really knows what they are doing with every game that they release. Although I am not a fan of the old Team Fortress Classic, I do believe that this game is fantastic. The style makes the game ooze uniqueness, distinguishing it from the gritty Call of Duty style shooters that often dominate today's gaming market. It's a fresh take on the FPS genre, (at least when it was released it was), and it shows this uniqueness through the gameplay.

The gameplay for this game is so varied that you can spend thousands of hours just playing the same 6 maps over and over again and still have a different gameplay experience everytime. You can customize your weapon loadouts with eaze. You can use the Force A Nature and Crit A Cola to become a machine that can mow down a whole enemy team in 5 seconds. You can use the Gunslinger and Frontier Justice to become an offensive powerhouse that can strike the unexpecting. The possibilites are endless and limitless. You can also find many funny people in the game, and because of this aspect, TF2 will be giving your hippocampus some more memory to fill, because you will remember many interestingly funny things that have happened in the game. I remember seeing a Spy and an Engie just having a sap and wrench battle, and the Engie wasn't even trying to do anything about it.

The cosmetics of the game also add a huge part of the game. While these things are indeed purely cosmetic (hence the name) they add a sense of individuality to the game, and it's hard to get that in FPS games today. Sure, there are paints that you can put on your weapons and skins that you can wear, but can you fully customize every little aspect of the character? There is a cosmetic that gives a merc and afro. There's one where you can follow every gamer stereotype ever and where a fedora. On top of that, you can make cosmetic sets, where you can use multiple cosmetic at once, to make your character as unique as possible.

Although, the game does come with a small bunch of flaws. Mainly balancing issues. As well as Valve changing things without ever thinking about the repercussions of adding those changes (I'm talking to you, Short Circuit). But through all that I'd give this game a 9/10

TL;DR; Fresh take on FPS genre with ifinite possibilites and unique style. TFTeam does suck. 9/10

Playing a game enough will often lead to fatigue. In the case of [i]Team Fortress 2[/i], a lack of any new content, at all, has basically killed off most interest in it. I would, unfortunately, recommend [i]Overwatch[/i] over this game every day of the week, much to the chagrin of the few loyal players that remain.

It is a great game! I have pretty much played for the majority of my gaming life and would still play it to this date as the fun first person shooter I have remembered it as. Team Fortress 2 is considered a great establishment in the fps genre and helped inspired many others - despite being aged, it still holds up decently against other titles with a community that makes it more lively whether in the casual, pub enviroment or the the competitive aspects (usually community driven like by ETF2L, UGC, RGL.gg, and so on). I would still consider it today as the enticing piece it is.

BEST GAME EVER LOVE IT. :3

Team Fortress 2 ou TF2 é um jogo muito show, jogado por equipes constituidas por vários jogadores e cujo objetivo é combater e ganhar ao adversário em cenários do género industrial, estações de comboios, etc…

A jogabilidade é semelhante a Quake, Unreal ou Counter Strike, mas em TF2 o jogo aborda um tema mais cartoon o que torna tudo mais animado. É também um jogo muito popular em comunidades e-sport ou competitivas e tal como League of Legends, há jogadores a ganharem muito dinheiro por vencerem as grandes competições.

Existem 9 classes militares para escolher, desde o artilheiro, engenheiro ou medico. As equipas tendem a usar várias classes para que haja uma melhor estratégia de combate. O jogo apresenta vários modos como o tradicional Capture-the-Flag (captura de bandeira), o King-of-the-Hill (rei da montanha) onde é ganhamos controlando territorio e também o mais simples como o Deathmatch ou Arena, onde o objetivo é matar mais do que o adversário.

Inicialmente desenvolvido como mod para o Quake, acabou por integrar a coleção da Valve e foi dos primeiros Jogos Free to Play ou F2P da Steam, juntamente com outros jogos como Spiral Knights, Forsaken World, Champions Online: Free For All, Global Agenda: Free Agent e Alliance of Valiant Arms.

Quase tão divertido como o jogo em si é o marketing da Valve para o jogo, o que coloca as personalidades das personagens para o primeiro plano em shorts de vídeo e histórias em quadrinhos on-line. Eles vão desde vídeos introdutórios, tais como “Meet the Medic” para filmes que exploram as histórias do universo de Team Fortress 2.

Valve também corre eventos especiais em torno de feriados como o Dia das Bruxas ou o Natal, com níveis e itens que os jogadores podem obter.
